item.title: By: ArthurZ
item.dc:creator: ArthurZ
item.description: You can also demote a project-level (AKA shared) connection manager back to the package level by right-clicking on it and choosing "Convert to Package Connection".
item.content:encoded: You can also demote a project-level (AKA shared) connection manager back to the package level by right-clicking on it and choosing “Convert to Package Connection”.

item.title: By: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.dc:creator: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.description: As I read that, I just described your every day .NET development language and platform. Well, close to it
item.content:encoded: As I read that, I just described your every day .NET development language and platform. Well, close to it

item.title: By: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.dc:creator: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.content:encoded:
Hmm..thinking about that and imaging creating dozens of dynamic and completely manipulative objects that can live in a catalog and be called simply by passing the right parameters to change how they process or function. Essentially taking a “package” down to an “object” and killing the need for multiple packages all together. Even more, there may not even be a need for anything other than a control flow. The control flow is the process handler and then all your shared objects are stored in a catalog such as the SSISDB where you can initialize them per the control flow.

Yeah, that might not happen but I likes the sounds of it ðŸ™‚

item.title: By: Jamie Thomson
item.dc:creator: Jamie Thomson
item.description: I wonder what other types of objects could be made shareable at the project level? Personally I'd like to have the ability to have a task or container live as a "thing" within the project that could then be instantiated within a package in the project. It'll never happen tho!!!!
item.content:encoded: I wonder what other types of objects could be made shareable at the project level? Personally I’d like to have the ability to have a task or container live as a “thing” within the project that could then be instantiated within a package in the project. It’ll never happen tho!!!!
